column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0089] At step 806, if no blocks against the sender are found in the conman table, an affirmative response is given and the process moves to step 808.
#Text=At step 808, the intended recipient's information is validated against a list of users in a user database or directory, as well as a user list in a destination server directory.
#Text=If the attempted transmission does not contain valid recipient information, a negative response is given at step 808 and the transmission is rejected.

#Text=Also, even if a valid recipient is found in the user database, if the recipient information is not also validated against the user list in the destination server database, the transmission may be rejected.
#Text=If validation from both the user database and the destination server database is obtained, an affirmation response is given and the process moves to step 810.
#Text=[0090] At step 810, a delivery manager table is queried to determine whether the intended message can be delivered to the destination server.
#Text=For example, the delivery manager table may be queried to determine if the destination server is capable of receiving the transmission or has it's load limit been reached.

#Text=If the destination server is not read to receive the message, an affirmation response is given at step 810 and the transmission attempt is deferred for delivery at a later time, once the destination server is ready to receive the message.
#Text=If the destination server is capable of receiving the message, a negative response is given at step 810 and the process moves to a step 812.
#Text=As indicated in the diagram, data regarding the sender and recipient has been written to the traffic monitor throughout this process.

#Text=[0091] At step 812, all of the data in the attempted transmission is received by the EMS, including header or other routing information, as well as the data forming the intended electronic message to be delivered.

#Text=The process then moves to step 814, where the configuration profile established by rules set forth by, for example, configuration settings for the user or the organization, are read in order to determine how to process the message.
#Text=At step 816, applications are employed to perform analysis of the message data to identify unwanted, prohibited or damaging messages.

#Text=Metadata associated with the results of this processing is written to the traffic monitor and used by the interpreter process to determine patterns or conditions used to establish connection and delivery guidelines.
#Text=Examples of the metadata created by using the applications are set forth above in Table 1.

#Text=[0092] Once the applications have completed the analysis, the process moves to step 818, where the results of the application processing are compared against the contents of the configuration database.
#Text=If the results of the application processing suggest an alternate disposition flag than the flag currently available for the message, a new disposition flag is inserted.
#Text=At step 820, the results from step 818 are compared to any disposition flags assigned to the message as were set forth in the conman table.

#Text=If, at step 820, a disposition flag indicating the attempted transmission will not be accepted at this time, the process moves to the appropriate step corresponding with the existing disposition flag in the conman table.
#Text=More specifically, if the message is to be spooled, the process moves to step 822.
#Text=If the message is to be quarantined, the process moves to step 824.
#Text=If the message is to be sent to a "black hole", the process moves to step 826.
#Text=If the message is to be deferred, the process moves to step 828.
#Text=If the message is to be redirected, the process moves to step 830.
#Text=[0093] However, if, at step 820, the records in the conman table establish that the transmission is to be accepted, the process moves to step 832.
#Text=At step 832, the message is transmitted to the intended destination sever.
#Text=At step 834, the message is received by the destination server.
#Text=At step 836, the destination server sends an acknowledgment of receipt of the message (an "ACK") back to the EMS to acknowledge receipt of the message from the delivery manager in the EMS.
#Text=Finally, at step 838, the EMS transmits an ACK of transmission back to the original sender of the message to inform the sender that the message has been transmitted to the targeted user.
#Text=The process then ends.
